results.definition: the act of retaining something
something owned; any tangible or intangible possession that is owned by someone;
examples: that hat is my property
he is a man of property

results.definition: keep in a certain state, position, or activity; e.g., "keep clean"
examples: hold in place
She always held herself as a lady
The students keep me on my toes

results.definition: have or hold in one's hands or grip
examples: Hold this bowl for a moment, please
A crazy idea took hold of him

results.definition: organize or be responsible for
examples: hold a reception
have, throw, or make a party
give a course

results.definition: have or possess, either in a concrete or an abstract sense
examples: She has $1,000 in the bank
He has got two beautiful daughters
She holds a Master's degree from Harvard

results.definition: keep in mind or convey as a conviction or view
examples: take for granted
view as important
hold these truths to be self-evident
I hold him personally responsible

results.definition: maintain (a theory, thoughts, or feelings)
examples: bear a grudge
entertain interesting notions
harbor a resentment

results.definition: to close within bounds, limit or hold back from movement
examples: This holds the local until the express passengers change trains
About a dozen animals were held inside the stockade
The illegal immigrants were held at a detention center
The terrorists held the journalists for ransom

results.definition: secure and keep for possible future use or application
examples: The landlord retained the security deposit
I reserve the right to disagree

results.definition: have rightfully; of rights, titles, and offices
examples: She bears the title of Duchess
He held the governorship for almost a decade

results.definition: be the physical support of; carry the weight of
examples: The beam holds up the roof
He supported me with one hand while I balanced on the beam
What's holding that mirror?

results.definition: contain or hold; have within
examples: The jar carries wine
The canteen holds fresh water
This can contains water

results.definition: have room for; hold without crowding
examples: This hotel can accommodate 250 guests
The theater admits 300 people
The auditorium can't hold more than 500 people

results.definition: remain in a certain state, position, or condition
examples: The weather held
They held on the road and kept marching

results.definition: support or hold in a certain manner
examples: She holds her head high
He carried himself upright

results.definition: be valid, applicable, or true
examples: This theory still holds

results.definition: assert or affirm
examples: Rousseau's philosophy holds that people are inherently good

results.definition: have as a major characteristic
examples: The novel holds many surprises
The book holds in store much valuable advise

results.definition: be capable of holding or containing
examples: This box won't take all the items
The flask holds one gallon

results.definition: arrange for and reserve (something for someone else) in advance
examples: reserve me a seat on a flight
The agent booked tickets to the show for the whole family
please hold a table at Maxim's

results.definition: protect against a challenge or attack
examples: Hold that position behind the trees!
Hold the bridge against the enemy's attacks

results.definition: bind by an obligation; cause to be indebted
examples: He's held by a contract
I'll hold you by your promise

results.definition: hold the attention of
examples: The soprano held the audience
This story held our interest
She can hold an audience spellbound

results.definition: remain committed to
examples: I hold to these ideas

results.definition: resist or confront with resistance
examples: The politician defied public opinion
The new material withstands even the greatest wear and tear
The bridge held

results.definition: be pertinent or relevant or applicable
examples: The same laws apply to you!
This theory holds for all irrational numbers
The same rules go for everyone

results.definition: stop dealing with
examples: hold all calls to the President's office while he is in a meeting

results.definition: lessen the intensity of; temper; hold in restraint; hold or keep within limits
examples: moderate your alcohol intake
hold your tongue
hold your temper
control your anger

results.definition: keep from departing
examples: Hold the taxi
Hold the horse

results.definition: take and maintain control over, often by violent means
examples: The dissatisfied students held the President's office for almost a week

results.definition: cause to stop
examples: Halt the engines
Arrest the progress
halt the presses

results.definition: cover as for protection against noise or smell
examples: She held her ears when the jackhammer started to operate
hold one's nose

results.definition: drink alcohol without showing ill effects
examples: He can hold his liquor
he had drunk more than he could carry

results.definition: aim, point, or direct
examples: Hold the fire extinguisher directly on the flames

results.definition: declare to be
examples: She was declared incompetent
judge held that the defendant was innocent

results.definition: be in accord; be in agreement
examples: We agreed on the terms of the settlement
I can't agree with you!
I hold with those who say life is sacred
Both philosophers concord on this point

results.definition: keep from exhaling or expelling
examples: hold your breath
